utterances: Hi, Neal.
How are you doing?
I'm well.
Thanks.
How has your business changed over the past couple of months?
Well, it's really changed in the amount of loans that we're doing.
We're seeing a lot of hard times out there and a lot people coming in and pawning their items to get the cash they need.
And those often come with some sad stories.
Yes, oftentimes.

I mean, I've seen - you know, just today, I had a, you know, tile worker and he said he'd much rather remodel a house and - to ensure that he gets paid rather than to contract out to do new homes, and not get paid.
Mm-hmm.
And he was pawning his gold ring, actually, to get some gas money.
So, I'm seeing that a lot.
That sounds like a wedding ring?
Yeah.
Yeah.
No, not really.
Well, a little bit, I should say.
Actually, I'm seeing a little bit of everybody as far as coming in.
I guess, my first initial thought there was that, you know, sales are down and redeems and interest payments are down.
I'm seeing - actually, I'm getting more calls from people that say, you know, please don't forfeit my stuff or please extend my due date.
I am working on trying to come up with the money and make the payment on the item.
I'm seeing a lot more that.
So, business maybe up but that doesn't necessarily mean that your revenue is up?
Exactly right.
I mean, the loans are up and we're helping a lot of people and we're seeing that.
And that's one of our main purposes.
That's what we want to do.
I mean, that's — our goal is to help people, and you can't walk into a bank with your good looks, and get the loan and walk out and pay your light bill.
But if you bring something that you have, a possession that you have that's of value and bring it in and get some money and take care of business.
So - but in doing that, I mean, I'm getting pretty stocked up here, and I've done a lot of loans.
And like you said, I mean, the revenue side isn't there.
And we mentioned sad stories before.
And sure - I'm sure a lot of those are true, but I'm sure you've heard an embellishment or two in your life.
Yeah.
Yeah.
You know, you're going to get that a little bit, people that are going to embellish a little bit, and, you know, about their hard times and what they're going through.
But I see a lot of people on foot even I've seen, you know, a Mercedes pull up off the street, take their cars through out, and walk down to pawn it to get gas.
You know, I'm seeing a lot of that kind of stuff.
It's just hard times.
I wonder, when you pawn the stereo out of a Mercedes Benz, do you get enough money to buy a tank full of gas?
Yeah, you do.
Of course.
Yeah.
I mean, usually we like to verify that the item works properly.
So, we take a chance on some items like that.
So, you still accept Blaupunkt?
Yeah.
Okay.
And you say fewer people are actually coming back to redeem their goods because, well, times are hard.
Yeah, that's right.
It used be around 70 percent, I think, and now it's dropped down maybe 50 percent, maybe even less, of people that come back to get their items.
Well, we hope that the revenue end of your business improves as well.
Thank you, sir.
Thank you, Neal.
Thanks for joining us.
You're welcome.
James Peacook, co-owner of the pawnshop in the Norcross, Georgia.
He joined us from there.
Here is a blog comment from Bob(ph) in Sausalito, California.
I'm a financial planner in Sausalito, California.
I work on an hourly basis so my practice attracts people from every hue of the economic spectrum, and my business is on fire - underline there.
I'm seeing people who see their stock portfolios deflate and the equity drained out of their homes.
They are suddenly nervous about retirement and rightly so.
Let's see if we can get another caller on the line.
And this is Mike(ph).
Mike with us from Boston.
Hi, Neal.
How are you?
Very well.
Thank you, Mike.
Good.
I work for a business called Eagle Vehicles, and we sell a lightweight, low-speed electric vehicle.
It can transport a person about 24 miles an hour up to a range of about 24 miles per charge.
Really?
And these are for sales?
Oh, yeah.
We've been in business for about seven years now.
And are the - you drive these on the streets of Boston?
Oh, yes, yes.
Boston and all over the country — Oregon, California, Florida.

And we find that a lot of people are looking for alternatives to get, you know, relatively short distances, whether be at the school or stores or the train station or their jobs even, you know, 15 miles, 20 miles for a single person in a car is really expensive.
But if you ride an Eagle cycle, it costs you about, you know, 7 or 8 cents to recharge it.
And you say cycles, so how big is this?
It's - think about a cross between a Vespa and a bicycle.
So, it's open-air, shall we say?
It is open air.
Yeah.
So, you wouldn't want to ride it in, you know, February in North Dakota.
And March in Boston either.
But it's April now, so your business I bet is picking up.
Prime time.
And I've noticed that our sales, as compared to last year, are up 20 percent already this year.
Up 20 percent.
And how many vehicles does that add up to?
I don't have an exact number, but…
Give us a ballpark.
It's pretty significant.
Several hundred, you know, probably 100 or 150 compared to last year.
All right, Mike, thanks very much.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
That's Mike from Boston.
Let's go now to Len(ph).
And Len is with us from East Grandview(ph) in Connecticut.
